slides.title: Welcome to Meteorology
slides.content:
# Introduction to Meteorology

Welcome to **Meteorology** - the study of weather and atmosphere!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Atmosphere** - Layers and composition
- **Weather** - Short-term conditions
- **Climate** - Long-term patterns
- **Severe Weather** - Storms and hazards

> **Fun Fact:** Weather vs Climate: Weather is what you wear today, climate is what clothes you have!

slides.title: The Atmosphere
slides.content:
# The Atmosphere

## Composition:
- Nitrogen: 78%
- Oxygen: 21%
- Argon: 0.9%
- CO2, water vapor, trace gases: 0.1%

## Layers:

| Layer | Altitude | Features |
|-------|----------|----------|
| Troposphere | 0-12 km | Weather occurs here |
| Stratosphere | 12-50 km | Ozone layer |
| Mesosphere | 50-80 km | Meteors burn up |
| Thermosphere | 80-700 km | Aurora, ISS |
| Exosphere | 700+ km | Fades to space |

## Key Properties:
- Temperature decreases with altitude (troposphere)
- Pressure decreases with altitude
- Most mass in troposphere

slides.title: Weather Factors
slides.content:
# Weather Factors

## Temperature:
- Sun heats Earth unevenly
- Warm air rises, cool air sinks

## Humidity:
- Amount of water vapor
- Relative humidity: % of maximum
- Dew point: Temperature for condensation

## Pressure:
- High pressure: Clear, calm
- Low pressure: Clouds, storms
- Wind flows from high to low

## Wind:
- Caused by pressure differences
- Coriolis effect: Curves due to Earth's rotation

## Clouds:

| Type | Altitude | Appearance |
|------|----------|------------|
| Cumulus | Low | Puffy, fair weather |
| Stratus | Low | Layered, overcast |
| Cirrus | High | Wispy, ice crystals |
| Cumulonimbus | Tall | Thunderstorms |

slides.title: Air Masses and Fronts
slides.content:
# Air Masses and Fronts

## Air Masses:
Large bodies of air with uniform properties.

| Type | Origin | Properties |
|------|--------|------------|
| Continental Polar (cP) | Land, high lat | Cold, dry |
| Maritime Polar (mP) | Ocean, high lat | Cold, moist |
| Continental Tropical (cT) | Land, low lat | Hot, dry |
| Maritime Tropical (mT) | Ocean, low lat | Warm, moist |

## Fronts:
Boundaries between air masses.

| Front | Symbol | Weather |
|-------|--------|--------|
| Cold | Blue triangles | Quick storms, temp drop |
| Warm | Red semicircles | Gradual rain, temp rise |
| Stationary | Both alternating | Prolonged rain |
| Occluded | Purple both | Complex weather |

slides.title: Severe Weather
slides.content:
# Severe Weather

## Thunderstorms:
- Cumulonimbus clouds
- Lightning, thunder, heavy rain
- Updrafts and downdrafts

## Tornadoes:
- Violently rotating column
- Fujita scale (F0-F5)
- Tornado Alley (US Great Plains)

## Hurricanes:
- Tropical cyclones
- Form over warm ocean (>26 C)
- Eye, eyewall, rainbands
- Saffir-Simpson scale (Cat 1-5)

## Winter Storms:
- Blizzards: heavy snow + wind
- Ice storms
- Lake effect snow

## Safety:
- Tornado: Shelter in interior room
- Hurricane: Evacuate or shelter
- Lightning: Stay indoors

slides.title: Climate
slides.content:
# Climate

## Definition:
Long-term average weather patterns.

## Climate Factors:
- Latitude
- Altitude
- Ocean proximity
- Ocean currents
- Prevailing winds
- Mountains (rain shadow)

## Climate Zones:

| Zone | Location | Characteristics |
|------|----------|----------------|
| Tropical | Equator | Hot, wet year-round |
| Dry | Subtropics | Low precipitation |
| Temperate | Mid-latitudes | Seasonal variation |
| Continental | Interior | Extreme seasons |
| Polar | High latitudes | Cold year-round |

## Climate Change:
- Rising global temperatures
- Greenhouse effect enhanced
- Melting ice, rising seas
- Changed weather patterns

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Meteorology Summary

## Atmosphere:
- 78% N2, 21% O2
- Weather in troposphere
- Ozone in stratosphere

## Weather Factors:
- Temperature, humidity, pressure, wind
- High pressure = fair; Low = storms

## Severe Weather:
| Type | Cause |
|------|-------|
| Thunderstorms | Unstable air |
| Tornadoes | Rotating updrafts |
| Hurricanes | Warm ocean |

## Climate vs Weather:
- Weather: Short-term
- Climate: Long-term average

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Meteorology!
